articles.title: Deno v. Oracle: Cancelling the JavaScript Trademark
articles.description: Did you know Oracle formally owns the ‘JavaScript’ trademark? There have been a few efforts to change this over the years but Oracle isn’t listening, so the Deno team formally filed a petition to cancel the trademark.
articles.author: Deno

articles.title: 🎂 JavaScript Turns 29 Years Old
articles.description: If you’re wondering why Oracle has the JavaScript trademark, it's because Sun owned the name and Oracle acquired Sun (which is also why it owns Java). As someone who was posting inane questions in comp.lang.javascript in 1996, this news makes me feel old – no-one could have anticipated what JavaScript would be today.
articles.author: Netscape and Sun Microsystems

articles.title: Astro 5.0: The Web Framework for Content-Driven Sites
articles.description: Astro has taken the front-end world by storm and v5.0 keeps up its rapid pace of development. Content Layer makes it easy to load content from any source and Server Islands can combine cached, static content with dynamic content. There’s now a type-safe way to manage environment variables and Vite 6 is along for the ride too. You can play with Astro 5 using the astro.new site.
articles.author: The Astro Team

articles.title: Take the State of JavaScript 2024 Survey
articles.description: Each year, Devographics runs a popular survey to see what JS features and tools you know about, use, and love/hate. It’s structured such that you can learn something just from taking it and the results are always interesting (see 2023’s). It’s open for a few more days, despite what the page says. (Or ▶️ watch someone else taking it?)
articles.author: Devographics

articles.title: 🤖 Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser
articles.description: Transformers.js is a seriously impressive project we link from time to time that lets you run pretrained machine learning models in the browser. Here’s a practical look at actually playing with it yourself right now.
articles.author: Raymond Camden

articles.title: Working with JavaScript's Scheduler API
articles.description: A look at an API only available in Chromium/Edge for now, but that promises a way to prioritize and control task execution in a more refined way than was possible till now.
articles.author: Trevor I. Lasn

articles.title: 📉 How To Improve 'Interaction to Next Paint' in React Apps
articles.description: Interaction to Next Paint (INP) is a Web performance metric based on the responsiveness of an app to user interactions – Google uses it as part of its ranking mechanism. Jacob offers up advice and resources for improving your INP scores in React apps.
articles.author: Jacob 'Kurt' Groß

articles.title: How Airtable Scaled TypeScript to Thousands of Projects
articles.description: “Today we have nearly 3000 TypeScript projects. That’s why we’re sharing our journey to so many projects, and how it reduced our typechecking time by 65%.”
articles.author: Michael Mitchell (Airtable)

articles.title: ▶  Building a Teleprompter App in 30 Minutes with AI
articles.description: Building apps with AI powered tools isn’t unusual nowadays, but if you’ve never been through the process, this is a good look at how it works all the way through to deployment.
articles.author: Kilian Ekamp

articles.title: Linkify 4.2: Link Up URLs, Emails, and More in Plain Text
articles.description: Given plain text containing things like links, hashtags, IP addresses, and email addresses, this will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Hypercontext

articles.title: Skia Canvas 2.0: A 'Browserless' Canvas Environment for Node.js
articles.description: Based on Google’s Skia engine and offers end results similar to Chrome’s own canvas system. GPU accelerated and can render images, paths, fonts, shapes, etc. v2.0 adds support for WOFF/WOFF2 fonts, WEBP, and more. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Christian Swinehart

articles.title: Math.js 14.0: An Extensive Math Library
articles.description: Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library continuing to get frequent updates. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Jos de Jong

articles.title: Onlook: 'Figma'-Like Design App for React
articles.description: A new open source, local-first design app (for Windows, Linux & macOS) targeting React apps. Design layouts directly on a live page and instantly write your changes to code. GitHub repo.
articles.author: On Off Inc.

articles.title: 🕒 SpaceTime 7.7: A Lightweight Timezone Library
articles.description: Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. Now updated for 2025. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Spencer Kelly

articles.title: BunBuster: A Fast Web and TCP Fuzzer for Brute Forcing Servers
articles.description: As always, use these sorts of things in a responsible way, but it’s interesting to see tools like this now being built in JavaScript, thanks to Bun’s speed and ease of distributing binaries.
articles.author: Tiago Rangel

articles.title: Kaluma: A Tiny JS Runtime for the Raspberry Pi Pico
articles.description: Can a JS runtime squeeze into 64KB to run on the RP2040-based Raspberry Pi Pico? Kaluma can, even while offering Node.js-style niceties.
articles.author: Kaluma Project

articles.title: Todoctor: A Tool to Analyze and Track TODO Comments
articles.description: A CLI tool designed to collect and monitor TODO/FIXME-style comments in JavaScript and TypeScript projects. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Azat S

articles.description: npmjs.com has a 'new, streamlined search experience. It's mostly a tweaking of the 'sort' options – so take a search like this one for 'svg', you can now sort by recent download counts and dependency levels.
TC39 News: Import Sync (explained here) is being promoted to stage 1, Error.isError moves to stage 3, and Intl.DurationFormat moves to stage 4.
🎄 Adrian Roselli has a roundup of development-themed advent calendars for you to enjoy this month, including Advent of TypeScript. 'Tis the season!
Porffor is an interesting ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler, now complete with a snazzy new homepage.
test262.fyi presents a technical view of how different JS engines fare on the official ECMAScript conformance suite.
TypeScript 5.7 – The final release of the typed JavaScript superset.
Node.js v22.12.0 (LTS) – A noteworthy release as it's the first Node LTS release with require(esm) enabled by default.
Radon IDE 1.0 – Turn VS Code or Cursor into a fully-fledged React Native IDE.
Prisma 6 – Powerful Node.js + TypeScript ORM.
Vite 6.0, React Router 7.0, Undici 7, ESLint v9.16.0, Meteor.js 3.1, Relay 18.2, Tailwind CSS v4.0 Beta, Redux Toolkit 2.4, Bun 1.1.38, NeutralinoJS 5.5

articles.title: A Layered Approach to Speculation Rules
articles.description: Harry has been experimenting with the Speculation Rules API, developing something of a multi-tiered approach to really maximizing the benefit of the two speculative loading types (prefetch and prerender).
articles.author: Harry Roberts

articles.title: Dataviz Accessibility Principles, Demonstrated by 2024 Presidential Election Dashboards
articles.description: Sarah has tested the accessibility of various 2024 U.S. Presidential Election data visualizations from various news orgs, looking at the charts and data on show and highlighting the numerous issues. A deep dive with some food for thought on accessible ways to display more complex information.
articles.author: Sarah Fossheim

articles.title: The Lowdown on Dropdowns in HTML & CSS
articles.description: If you’re trying to reveal content from user interaction David proclaims that “you should read this”, encouraging us to put down that JavaScript and check out new and upcoming HTML/CSS features to help us do the job.
articles.author: David Darnes

articles.title: Frosted Glass from Games to the Web
articles.description: A UI games developer (who worked on the Forza series) shares the process of translating in-game ‘frosted acrylic’ design elements to HTML. The end result is nice! backdrop-filter does the heavy lifting here.
articles.author: Tyler Wolf Leonhardt

articles.title: Creating Effective Multi-Step Forms
articles.description: Looks at the design considerations for good-form experiences, beyond just validation — specifically on forms that involve navigation between sections.
articles.author: Amejimaobari Ollornwi

articles.title: Starting Off Right: Where Autofocus Shines
articles.description: On the value of autofocus for enhancing the user experience, particularly on form-heavy single purpose pages.
articles.author: Kilian Valkhof

articles.title: Tailwind Colors: All The Tailwind CSS Colors in a 'Cheatsheet'
articles.description: You can click to copy any color and choose the desired format, which includes the new OKLCH format that gets transpiled to a more common format with Tailwind version 4.
articles.author: tailscan

articles.title: Kinesis.js: A Library to Easily Create Complex Interactive Animations
articles.description: The home page includes some advanced examples of what’s possible, which includes the ability to animate elements in response to mouse movement, scroll events, and even audio frequency data. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Amine Bouyarmane

articles.title: uifonts.app: Test and Preview Fonts in Real Time
articles.description: The fonts, sourced from Google Fonts, are displayed on real UI elements on the page. You can select a primary and secondary font or hit the ‘random’ button to preview random font pairings.
articles.author: uifonts․app

articles.title: Spark UI: A Library of Animated Components Built with Vue, TypeScript, Tailwind, and Vueuse Motion
articles.description: See some demos here.
articles.author: Selemon Brahanu
